metadata.sermon_title: Philadelphia: The Keepers Are Kept, Part 1
metadata.sermon_start_end: It has become clear to me that I shall need perhaps one more Sunday, maybe two, but one more certainly after this, in connection with this church at Philadelphia. Today I want to talk about "The Keepers Are Kept." I do not know how it is with you [...] When the New Testament says to you and me to be patient, it is not talking about dumb submission, surrender, and resignation. It is not. That word patience has been misused. Christian people are not called on quietly and calmly and meekly to submit to everything.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on a specific phrase within Revelation 3:8 ('Thou hast a little strength'). However, it spends significant time on anecdotes and other biblical books (Corinthians, Genesis) before arriving at the text. It identifies a specific tension in the text—the ambiguity of 'little strength'—but fails to articulate what is unique to this passage that cannot be found elsewhere.
quotes: particularly what I want you to look at is this, 'Thou hast a little strength.'
The meaning may well be thou hast but a little strength... Or, the meaning may be you do have some strength.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific 'Philadelphia' context more sharply. Why does *this* church receive this specific word compared to the others? Avoid the long anecdotal introduction.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is thin. While the preacher mentions 'New Testament scholars' and 'etymology,' there is no actual engagement with the historical context of Philadelphia or the linguistic nuances of the Greek text. The preacher uses the text as a springboard for moral philosophy rather than unfolding the original context.
quotes: There are New Testament scholars who take either side of what I am about to say.
I was so troubled by it that I went back to get its etymology.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Provide concrete historical data about Philadelphia (the city/church) and explain the Greek term 'hypomonē' (patience) rather than just stating that an etymological study was done.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part of the sermon. It is highly concrete, addressing the drug trade, local politics in Brooklyn, and racial voting patterns. It avoids 'general truths' by naming specific industries ($65 billion drug trade) and specific social tensions.
quotes: We have drugs sweeping through this country... the drug industry is now $65 billion.
All of us are terribly distressed because the Jewish community gave to the candidate who happened to be black only 12 or 13 percent of its vote.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows directly from the text's revelation rather than using the text as a hook for social commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of blocks. It moves from a long personal anecdote to a brief textual observation, then to a long socio-political application. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' so much as the text is used to validate the preacher's observations on society.
quotes: I want to give you this morning a formula for making this a far better world. Are you ready for it? Here it is...
I hope you're going to get the difference here I'm trying to draw this morning.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the social analysis into the reading of the verse itself so that the 'present of revelation' occurs within the biblical word.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' of the drug trade and social division is present, but it is treated more as a sociological problem than a theological 'misery before God.' Redemption is hinted at through 'grace' and 'Jesus died for all,' but the focus remains heavily on human effort ('use what little strength we do have').
quotes: We will never get rid of this plague until we are all committed to using what little strength we do have.
You and I are not equal to the issues of our lives by ourselves.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by showing how our 'little strength' is a spiritual condition before God, not just a lack of political power.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present only in a secularized form: the choice between social healing or social poison. The ultimate seriousness of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) in relation to God's judgment is absent. The tone is more of a civic appeal than a theological ultimatum.
quotes: We can remember from wherever this poison has come as we face the next election.
This city is broken and bruised and divided.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematize the 'open door' that 'no man can shut' as a divine opportunity that carries the weight of eternal consequence.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned toward the end as the one who 'died for all,' but he is not the telos of the sermon's logic. The sermon's goal is primarily moral and social reform ('be hard on yourself and easy on others'). Christ is an example or a message to be shared rather than the life-giving center.
quotes: while you may not be able to preach like Paul... you can tell somebody that Jesus died for all.
The Lord Jesus says to this church in Philadelphia...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the source of the 'little strength' rather than just the subject of a message we are supposed to tell others.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. More importantly, the 'breadth' is filled with personal anecdotes rather than theological 'depth.' It lacks the substantive weight Dekker requires.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Replace the first 5 minutes of personal reminiscence with deeper exegetical and dogmatic reflection on the nature of God's strength in human weakness.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily because it functions more as a socio-political address than a recreative proclamation of the Word of God. It lacks rigorous exegesis (Thesis 2) and fails to maintain Christ as the telos (Thesis 7). While the application is concrete, it borders on a 'formula for a better world' which Dekker warns against as 'general truths.'
strengths: Concrete application: The preacher avoids vague pieties by addressing specific local issues like the drug trade and racial tensions in Brooklyn.
Specific textual focus: The sermon correctly identifies a specific tension in the phrase 'little strength' as the pivot point.
weaknesses: Anecdotal weight: The first third of the sermon is occupied by personal memories that do not contribute to the exposition of the text.
Moralism: The 'formula' for a better world shifts the focus from God's action to human ethical behavior.
Lack of theological depth: Dogma and exegesis are not 'sleeping' (as Dekker requires of prior knowledge) but are largely absent, replaced by sociology.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate social speech, but it is not a sermon in the Dekkerian sense. It lacks the 'depth' that requires 'breadth' and subordinates the specific revelation of the Bible passage to a general call for civic virtue.
